name: Sitar
description: A long-necked, plucked stringed instrument from the Indian subcontinent. It features a gourd resonator, a wide neck with movable frets, and a set of sympathetic strings that resonate in response to the main strings, creating a rich, layered sound.

name: Djembe
description: A rope-tuned, skin-covered goblet drum from West Africa, played with bare hands. It produces a wide range of tones and is traditionally an integral part of community life, used in ceremonies and celebrations.

name: Great Highland Bagpipes
description: An aerophone from Scotland consisting of a bag reservoir, a blowpipe for inflation, a chanter for melody, and three drones that produce a constant harmonic background.

name: Koto
description: The national instrument of Japan, a long board zither traditionally made of paulownia wood, with thirteen silk strings stretched over movable bridges.

name: Yidaki / Didgeridoo
description: A natural trumpet developed by the Aboriginal peoples of northern Australia, made from eucalyptus branches hollowed out by termites and played using a circular breathing technique.

name: Oud
description: A pear-shaped, short-necked, fretless lute foundational to music across the Middle East and North Africa. Its fretless neck enables the use of microtonal intervals common in regional music.

name: Mbira
description: A lamellaphone ('thumb piano') of the Shona people of Zimbabwe, featuring staggered metal keys on a wooden soundboard. It is often placed inside a gourd resonator to amplify its sound.

name: Steelpan
description: A pitched percussion instrument created in Trinidad and Tobago from 55-gallon oil drums. The drum's surface is hammered into distinct, tuned note-producing areas.

name: Theremin
description: An early electronic instrument played without physical contact. The musician controls pitch and volume by moving their hands in the proximity of two antennas that create an electromagnetic field.

name: Electric Guitar
description: A guitar that uses one or more electromagnetic pickups to convert the vibration of its strings into electrical signals, which are then routed to an amplifier.

name: Piano
description: A keyboard instrument where felt-covered hammers strike steel strings. It is known for its wide dynamic range, controlled by the player's touch on the keys.

name: Violin
description: A four-stringed bowed instrument with a fretless fingerboard. It is the highest-pitched member of the violin family and central to Western classical music.

name: Acoustic Guitar
description: A stringed instrument that produces sound acoustically through the vibration of its strings, amplified by its hollow wooden body.

name: Trumpet
description: A brass instrument with the highest register in its family. Sound is produced by buzzing lips into a mouthpiece, with pitch altered by pressing three valves.

name: Flute
description: A family of aerophones that produces sound from the flow of air across an opening. While ancient forms were end-blown, the modern concert flute is a transverse (side-blown) instrument.

name: Drum Set
description: A collection of drums, cymbals, and other percussion instruments arranged to be played by a single person, forming the rhythmic foundation in many genres of music.

name: Saxophone
description: A single-reed woodwind instrument with a conical brass body and keyed fingering system, commonly used in jazz, classical, and popular music.

name: Cello (Violoncello)
description: A large, low-pitched bowed string instrument of the violin family, played while seated. It is known for its rich tone, which is said to be close to the human voice.

name: Clarinet
description: A single-reed woodwind instrument with a cylindrical bore. It is known for its wide range and agile, expressive sound across different registers.

name: Electric Bass
description: An electrically amplified stringed instrument, modeled on the electric guitar, designed to be played in the bass clef register to provide a harmonic and rhythmic foundation.

name: Harp
description: An ancient stringed instrument with strings positioned at an angle to its soundboard, played by plucking with the fingers. Modern orchestral harps use pedals to alter pitch.

name: Trombone
description: A brass instrument that uses a telescoping slide mechanism, rather than valves, to change pitch. It is known for its ability to produce a perfect glissando.

name: Banjo
description: A stringed instrument, developed by enslaved Africans in the Americas, with a circular body covered by a thin membrane that serves as a resonator.

name: Oboe
description: A double-reed woodwind instrument with a conical bore. It is known for its clear and penetrating tone and is often used to sound the tuning note for an orchestra.

name: Xylophone
description: A percussion instrument consisting of tuned wooden bars arranged like a keyboard. It produces short, bright tones when struck with mallets.

name: Accordion
description: A portable, box-shaped aerophone played by compressing or expanding a bellows while pressing buttons or keys, causing air to flow across free reeds.

name: French Horn
description: A brass instrument made of over 20 feet of coiled tubing that flares into a wide bell. Pitch is controlled by a combination of lip tension, airflow, and rotary valves.

name: Ukulele
description: A small, four-stringed member of the lute family that originated in Hawaii, based on Portuguese stringed instruments. It is known for its bright, cheerful sound.

name: Marimba
description: A percussion instrument similar to a xylophone but with broader, more resonant wooden bars. Each bar is paired with a resonator tube, which amplifies its sound.
